ext_descriptions.ext_description:
A mesh is defined by its vertices and the connections between the vertices. A mesh is a connected graph.
Structured mesh
In a structured mesh the cells are arranged in a regular pattern and their shapes are implied by the particular kind of mesh.
A 3–D rectangular mesh is a mesh of hexahedral cells. Each cell is a dimensionality 3 hexahedral region defined by eight vertices forming the corners of the hexahedron. Each cell is bounded by six faces, where each face is the quadrilateral defined by four vertices. A face is limited by the four edges that connect the four vertices.
Example convention for a 2-D cell centre
Example mesh with rind vertices
A 2–D rectangular mesh is a mesh of quadrilaterals. Each cell is a dimensionality two quadrilateral region defined by four vertices forming the corners of the quadrilateral. Each cell is limited by the four edges that connect the four vertices.
A 1–D mesh is of linear form. Each cell is a dimensionality one linear region bounded by two vertices.
Indices describing a structured mesh are ordered: for 3–D (i, j, k); (i, j) is used for 2–D; and (i) for 1–D.
Cell centres, face centres, and edge centres are indexed by the minimum of the connecting vertices.
For example a 2-D cell center (or face centre on a 3-D mesh) would have the conventions shown in Figure 1.
In addition, the default beginning vertex for a regular mesh is (1, 1, 1); this means the default beginning cell centre of a regular mesh is also (1, 1, 1).
There may be locations outside the mesh itself. These are referred to as 'rind' or ghost points and may be associated with fictitious vertices or cell centres. They are distinguished from the vertices and cells making up the mesh (including its boundary vertices), which are referred to as 'core' points.
Figure 2 shows a 2–D mesh with a single row of 'rind' vertices at the minimum and maximum i-faces.
The mesh size (i.e., the number of 'core' vertices in each direction) is 5×4. 'Core' vertices are designated by '•', and 'rind' vertices by '×'. Default indexing is also shown for the vertices.
For a mesh, the minimum faces in each coordinate direction are denoted i-min, j-min and k-min; the maximum faces are denoted i-max, j-max and k-max. These are the minimum and maximum 'core' faces.
The value i-min denotes the face or mesh plane whose core vertices have minimum i index (which if using default indexing is 1).
Unstructured mesh
An unstructured mesh is composed of cells, where the cells need not form a regular pattern and the shape of the cells is not restricted to be uniform throughout the mesh. Cells have vertices at their corners and may also have nodes on cell edges, cell faces, and in the interior of the cell.
Each cell in an irregular mesh has at least one vertex in common with at least one other cell in the mesh. The connectivity and adjacency of the cells may be determined from the common vertices.
Each cell in an unstructured mesh is explicitly represented in terms of its shape and an ordered list of its vertices. The vertices are implied rather than being explicitly represented. Essentially all the vertices in a mesh can be mapped to a sequential list, and reference to a vertex is then equivalent to specifying the particular position in the list.
A cell_shape is an identifier of an unstructured mesh cell shape.
A cell_shape_0d is an identifier of a topologically 0–D unstructured mesh cell shape.
a singleton vertex.
A cell_shape_1d is an identifier of a topologically 1-D unstructured mesh cell shape.
a topological line requiring 2 vertices.
A cell_shape_2d is an identifier of a topologically 2-D unstructured mesh cell shape.
four sided cell requiring 4 vertices;

ext_description.p: three sided cell requiring 3 vertices.
ext_description.note: This type is defined as EXTENSIBLE to enable other 2D cell shapes to be added to the list as required by particular applications.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A cell_shape_3d is an identifier of a topologically 3-D unstructured mesh cell shape.
hexahedral (six quadrilateral faces) requiring 8 vertices;
pentahedral (three quadrilateral faces and two triangular faces) requiring 6 vertices;
tetrahedral form (four triangular faces) requiring 4 vertices;

ext_description.p: pyramidal (one quadrilateral face and four triangular faces) requiring 5 vertices.
ext_description.note: This type is defined as EXTENSIBLE to enable other 3D cell shapes to be added to the list as required by particular applications.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: An element_order specifies the allowable geometric order of the element interpolation functions of a finite element.
the element basic interpolation order is linear;
the element basic interpolation order is quadratic;
the element basic interpolation order is cubic.
An indices_group is a selection of a group of indices into a multi-dimensional array.
A mesh_location is an enumeration of locations with respect to a mesh.
not specified;
specified via an external agreement between the data creator and the data user;
at cell vertices for cells within the mesh;
the center of a cell; this is also appropriate for entities associated with cells but not necessarily with a given location in a cell;
the center of a generic face which can point in any coordinate direction;
the center of a face in 3-D whose computational normal points in the i direction;
the center of a face in 3-D whose computational normal points in the j direction;
the center of a face in 3-D whose computational normal points in the k direction;
the center of an edge.

A mesh_maths_space_type is an enumeration of the kinds of associations of a
and a .
data is associated with mesh cells;
data is associated with mesh vertices.
A structured_mesh_type is an enumeration of the kinds of structured meshes.

ext_description.p: a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, quadrilateral in 2-D, and hedral in 3-D, etc.
In 2–D the cells are all quadrilateral. In 3–D the cells are all hexahedral.
ext_description.note: Illustrations of rectangular mesh topologies are shown in Figure 3, Figure 4 and Figure 5.

figure.title: A 1-D rectangular mesh or pentahedral mesh or pyramidal mesh or tetrahedral mesh (with i = 5)

ext_description.p: a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, triangular in 2-D, and pentahedral, with 2 triangular and 3 quadrilateral faces forming a wedge-like shape, in 3-D (where one of the edges between a pair of rectangular faces is analogous to the axis of a sector of a cylinder).

It is convenient to think of this kind of mesh as like a sector of a circle in 2–D where one apex point is anolagous to the centre point of the circle, and like a sector of a cylinder in 3–D where one of the edges between a pair of rectangular faces is analogous to the axis of the cylinder.
In 2–D the cells adjacent to the apex are triangular; the rest are quadrilateral.
In 3–D the cells adjacent to the axis edge are pentahedral; the rest are hexahedral.
ext_description.note: Illustrations of pentahedral mesh topologies are shown in Figure 3, Figure 6 and Figure 7.

figure.title: A 3-D rectangular mesh (with i = 5, j = 4, k = 3)
A 2-D pentahedral mesh or pyramidal mesh or tetrahedral mesh (with i = 5, j = 4)
A 3-D pentahedral mesh (with i = 5, j = 4, k = 3)

ext_description.p: a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, triangular in 2-D, and pyramidal in 3-D.

It is convenient to think of this kind of mesh as like a sector of a circle in 2–D where one apex point is analogous to the centre point of the circle, and like a sector of a sphere in 3–D where the apex point is analogous to the centre point of a sector of the sphere.
In 2–D the cells adjacent to the apex are triangular; the rest are quadrilateral.
In 3–D the cells adjacent to the apex are pyrimidal; the rest are hexahedral.
ext_description.note: Illustrations of pyramidal mesh topologies are shown in Figure 3, Figure 6 and Figure 8.

ext_description.p: a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, triangular in 2-D, and tetrahedral in 3-D.

figure.title: A 3-D pyramidal mesh (with i = 5, j = 4, k = 3)
A 3-D tetrahedral mesh (with i = 5, j = 4, k = 3)

ext_description.p: In 2–D the cells adjacent to the apex are triangular; the remainder are quadrilateral.
In 3–D the cells adjacent to the apex are tetrahedral and the cells adjacent to one edge from the apex are pentahedral; the remainder are hexahedral.
ext_description.note: Illustrations of tetrahedral mesh topologies are shown in Figure 3, Figure 6 and Figure 9.

ext_description.p: A Product_of_mesh is a relationship that is between:

ul.li:
two operands that are a 1-dimensional
and an n-dimensional ; and

ext_description.p:
that indicates the (n + 1)-dimensional
is the Cartesian product of the operands.

The ordering of cells and vertices of the product
is:

ul.li: cell i + n(j - 1) of the product mesh corresponds to cell i of the first operand and cell j of the second operand, where n is the total number of cells of the first operand;
vertex i + m(j - 1) of the product mesh corresponds to vertex i of the first operand, and vertex j of the second operand, where m is the total number of vertices of the first operand.

A Rind is the number of rind planes associated with a structured mesh.
the number of indices required to reference a vertex.

ext_description.p: contains the number of rind planes attached to the minimum and maximum faces of a structured mesh. The face corresponding to each index n of planes in 3-D is:
n = 1 ⟶ i-min n = 2 ⟶ i-max
n = 3 ⟶ j-min n = 4 ⟶ j-max
n = 5 ⟶ k-min n = 6 ⟶ k-max

ext_description.p:
A Structured_mesh is a type of
that has a regular topology. A Structured_mesh has a parametric coordinate system; the parametric coordinate systems for one- two-, and three-dimensional structured meshes are shown in Figure 10 through Figure 12.

figure.title: Parametric coordinate system for a 1-D structured mesh
Parametric coordinate system for a 2-D structured mesh
Parametric coordinate system for a 3-D structured mesh

ext_description.p: For each cell within a Structured_mesh, the parametric coordinate system for that cell is identical to the parametric coordinate system for the mesh, except for an origin shift. The parametric coordinates of vertex (i, j, k) in a 3-D mesh with n, m and p cells in the 3 dimensions are:

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
the number of vertices in each dimension of the mesh. The product of the array elements is the number of vertices defining the mesh (i.e., excluding any rind points). The number of vertices in one- two- and three-dimensional regular mesh topologies is given in Table 1, where i, j and k correspond to the array elements vertex_counts[1], vertex_counts[2] and vertex_counts[3], respectively.
Index count Rectangular Pentahedral Pyramidal Tetrahedral
1 i i i i
2 ij j(i - 1) + 1 j(i - 1) + 1 j(i - 1) + 1
3 ijk jk(i - 1) + k jk(i - 1) + 1 jk(i - 1) - (i - 2)(j - 1)
the number of cells in each dimension of the mesh. The product of the array elements is the number of cells on the interior of the mesh.
the kind of mesh.

A Structured_mesh_with_rind is a type of
with specified rind planes.

the
planes associated with the mesh.

A Submesh is a type of
that is part of another . The Submesh is related to the parent
by an
relationship. The cells of the Submesh are not necessarily connected.

ext_description.p: An Unstructured_mesh is a type of . An Unstructured_mesh is composed of cells, where the cells do not form a regular pattern and the shape of the cells is not uniform throughout the mesh. Cells have vertices at the ends of cell edges, and may also have nodes on cell edges, cell faces and in the interior of the cell.

It conceptually consists of the vertices of the mesh and the cells forming the volume of the mesh. The cells shall all be connected by each cell having at least one vertex in common with another cell. The shape of each cell in an unstructured mesh is explicitly specified.
ext_description.note: A vertex at the corner of a cell is a cell vertex.
ext_description.p:
An Unstructured_mesh is either an
or an .

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the number of cells in the mesh.

A Vertex_defined_cell is a type of
that is defined by its vertices. The number of vertices depends on the topological shape of the cell. The cell may have edge, face and interior vertices. The maximum number of edge, face and interior vertices depends on both the shape and the order of the cell.
the topological shape of the cell.
the order of the cell geometric interpolation.

ext_description.p:
the vertices at the ends of cell edges, and within cell edges, cell faces and the interior of the cell. The position of a vertex or an edge node in the array depends on the shape of the cell as established graphically in ISO 10303-104, noting that a polygon cell is a generalisation of the
and
cells.
ext_description.note: For convenience, most of the ISO 10303-104 Figures have been redrawn in this part of ISO 10303 as Figure 13 to Figure 19, where a vertex or edge node is indicated by a dot. The vertex labelled '1' is the first index in the array, that labelled '2' is the second index in the array, and so on. Edge and face information from ISO 10303-104 is given in Table 2 to Table 4.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the number of cell bounding vertices; it is determined by the value of shape.
the number of interior cell nodes located on the cell edges; it is determined by the combination of the values of shape and order.

ext_description.p: the potential number of interior cell nodes which are not located on the cell edges; it is determined by the combination of the values of shape and order.
ext_description.note: In Figure 13 to Figure 19 the non-edge interior nodes are indicated by circles.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the total number of bounding vertices plus the number of edge nodes.
the total number of bounding vertices plus the number of nodes (both edge and non-dege nodes).
the vertices and nodes excluding any non-edge interior nodes. There shall be required_count of these.

The function all_mesh_vertices takes an
as its argument and returns TRUE if the members of the
attribute are exactly the vertices in the mesh.
an .

The function cell_counts takes a
as its argument and returns the numbers of vertices and nodes required to define the cell. Returns a 3 element array of INTEGER, where the first element is the number of vertices defining the bounds of the cell, the second is the number of interior nodes located on an edge, and the third is the maximum number of (potential) interior nodes not located on an edge.
a .
The function shorten_array inputs a one dimensional array and returns a shorter one dimensional array containing the first newl elements of the input array.
the input array.
the number of elements in longa.
the smaller number of elements in the output array.
A function this_schema returns a STRING containing the name of the schema.
